Award.AbstractNarration:
Golden
DMS-1009704

The investigator and his colleagues conduct fundamental
mathematical and numerical studies of phase transitions in
composite materials, with applications to electrorheological (ER)
fluids and sea ice, which share similar microstructural features.
They develop a statistical mechanics framework in which such
transitions can be studied, and explore random matrix
characterizations of composite microstructures and their
evolution. One central problem to be addressed is the existence
of a critical electric field necessary to induce the fluid/solid
transition in ER fluids. They anticipate that this phenomenon
goes beyond classical phase transitions in statistical mechanics,
representing a new type of transitional mechanism that depends on
a competition between geometrical entropy and electrical energy.
They also study the fluid transport and related microstructural
transition in sea ice, which plays a key role in Earth's climate
system. Such microstructures can be identified with random
matrices, and the investigators study the evolution of
microstructural features with such techniques.

Composite materials arise throughout the physical and
biological sciences and across most types of engineering. One of
the key features of these types of problems is the critical
dependence of the effective material properties on the parameters
characterizing the system. For example, an electrorheological
(ER) fluid is a suspension of particles in a viscous fluid such
as oil. If an applied electric field exceeds a critical value
then the particles form chains and the suspension undergoes a
fluid/solid transition within milliseconds. This electrically
induced transition has been used in applications including next
generation clutches, brakes, micro-fluidic valves, and human
prosthetics. Another example is sea ice, a composite of pure ice
with brine inclusions, which plays a key role in Earth's climate
system. If the temperature exceeds a critical value, then fluid
can flow through the ice. This transition mediates a broad range
of processes in the polar ice packs that are fundamental to
making better predictions of climate change. The investigator
and colleagues conduct fundamental mathematical and numerical
studies of these transitions in ER fluids and sea ice. They
bring to bear sophisticated techniques of theoretical statistical
physics to better understand the behavior of these types of
materials. Through these studies, the investigator anticipates
the development of applications to other high-tech composites and
to other areas critical to our understanding of polar climate
change.

The project is cofunded by the Division of Mathematical Sciences
and the Division of Materials Research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Composite materials arise naturally throughout the physical and biological sciences, and are employed in a broad range of engineering, technological and medical applications. The behavior of those media exhibiting a critical transition as system parameters are varied is particularly challenging to describe physically, and to predict mathematically.

 

For example electrorheological fluids are suspensions of particles in a viscous liquid such as oil.  As the strength of an applied electric field surpasses a critical value, the particles become bound together, forming connected structures, and the suspension exhibits a liquid to solid phase transition. Such systems have been used in clutches, brakes, micro-fluidic valves, and human prosthetics.

 

Another inhomogeneous medium that displays complex critical behavior is sea ice, which plays an important role in the climate system, and hosts extensive algal and bacterial communities sustaining life in the polar oceans. As a material, sea ice is a composite of pure ice with sub-millimeter scale brine inclusions, whose volume fraction, geometry, and connectedness vary significantly with temperature. In fact, for temperatures below a critical value, sea ice is impermeable to fluid flow. However, for temperatures above this critical level, the brine inclusions coalesce to form long pathways and channels. This allows fluid to flow, mediating a broad range of processes such as the growth and decay of seasonal ice, the evolution of surface melt ponds and ice pack reflectance, the transfer of gas and nutrients, and biomass buildup.

 

In this project we developed powerful mathematical techniques to analyze, model, and predict the behavior of composites that exhibit phase transitions as some parameter like temperature, volume fraction, or applied field is varied. Our work shows that key statistical measures of the microstructure exhibit a transition that is strikingly similar to universal behavior found in other problems unrelated to composites. In the context of electrorheological fluids, we have developed a statistical mechanics approach to modeling the fluid/solid transition, which can be applied in other settings as well. The results of this project have helped lay the mathematical underpinnings of understanding the percolation transition in sea ice, and its implications for sea ice processes, both climatological and biogeochemical. Furthermore, the foundational work on computing the effective properties of composite media can be applied to important composites such as sea ice. For example, effective electromagnetic properties, which are important in sea ice remote sensing from satellites, can be found using many of the techniques in this project.

 

The mathematical framework we have developed and applied in detail to the brine microstructure can be naturally extended to larger scales. In particular, our homogenization analysis can be applied to the sea ice pack itself, a composite of ice floes and ocean, as well as the evolving mosaic of ice and melt ponds on the surface of melting Arctic sea ice. In conclusion, the research funded by this NSF grant strives to improve our mathematical understanding of phase transitions in composite materials, and explore the impact of these mathematical advances in important application areas such as modeling the role of sea ice in the climate system, and improving our physical understanding and practical use of the electrorheological transition.
